text: â™ª Ohhh ohhh ohhh â™ª
Naomi's okay with it? Yes.
With you and me, she's okay with it?
Yes.
You told her we were sleeping together,
and she's fine with that?
Sam. No, I'm just saying.
Her ex-husband and best friend
doing all kinds of pervy, hot, nasty, sexy...
Okay, she was surprised, yes,
but, you know, we drank some wine.
We did what we do, and in the end, she was fine.
I mean, it's okay. She's okay.
If you say so.
Sam, why can't you believe that she's okay?
Would you be?
Running's for idiots.
Oh, it's so good having you living here again.
It makes my mornings 100 percent more interesting.
And the evenings? Whew.
Yeah, they're pretty awesome too.
Whoa. Hey, could you hold that? Whew.
Where you going? Fifth floor.
Me too.
First visit?
Yeah. I've, uh, been avoiding this.
Don't worry. You're gonna love everybody in there.
Oh, sorry. Hey.
You cannot be here.
Who needs cereal when you can have chocolate cupcakes?
You take my husband and all I get are chocolate cupcakes?
Wha--? Uh...
Wow, as far as guilt gifts go,
you kind of cheaped out a little.
No, no, Nai. That's not what this is. I, uh...
I didn't mean to, um...
I'm kidding.
Oh.
Good. I'm fine, Addison.
I'm okay. I'm fine. We're fine.
Mm. Okay.
Well, um, thank you for being so understanding, Nai.
Well, I'm not doing it for you.
With Dell and Maya and William, I'm just, uh--
I'm letting it all go.
I'm just-- I'm done carrying around all my anger.
Sam: Get the hell out of here.
Get the hell out of here. Pete: Easy, Sam.
You got some nerve showing up like this.
I need to talk to you. What's going on?
It's the guy that hit Maya and Dell.
Hagen: I am so sorry.
No. No. You don't get a chance to be sorry.
He doesn't get a chance to apologize.
Is that--? That's the guy.
I would give anything to take it back, but I can't.
Look, I made a deal with the prosecutor. I'm being sentenced.
I'll go to jail. I deserve that. But I just wanted--
I don't know. If you could forgive me?
Sam! Hey!
As far as I'm concerned-- Addison: Let him go. Sam.
--You shouldn't even be alive.
Let him go right now, Sam. Cooper: Sam.
Someone call 911.
Hagen: Oh, my chest. Addison: Get the oxygen.
Take slow, deep breaths. Breathe. Breathe.
Sam, I know you're upset, but to choke this man...
Do you--? Do you know I'm upset?
Yes, of course, I understand, but...
Sam: Because you should've been choking him with me.
Why? Instead of standing back...
What do you expect me to do? I expect you to back me up.
Back you up? She's your daughter.
Of course. I want you to remember.
Naomi: I went through the same thing.
Sam: Remember her in that bed.
What's that about? Chickens coming home to roost.
What if you killed that man? We...
Can somebody translate?
The guy who killed Dell showed up to apologize.
And Sam took matters into his own hands literally, like:
Well, good for Sam.
The guy should've just crawled into a hole and disappeared.
Give the guy credit for having the guts
to walk through the door and face all of us.
He had to know the reception he was gonna get.
Pete: If he almost killed my kid,
I'd make sure he rotted in prison for the rest of his life.
Don't you have things to do? Charlotte: I don't think so.
I'm kind of clear.
Naomi: I hate what he did every bit as much as you,
but that doesn't mean you can go and attack him.
Why are you defending him? I am not defending him, Sam.
But he did come here to apologize.
Apologize?
Apologize for killing Dell and almost killing our daughter?
What kind of apology--? Sam, I don't know!
I don't know. You didn't give the man a chance to speak.
I spoke to the hospital and, um,
Troy hagen is stable,
but his EKG does show signs of new changes.
Sam, are you okay?
I don't know what that guy needs to say to make you feel good
about him getting drunk and driving into Maya and Dell.
He killed a man. He doesn't get my forgiveness.
Maybe you can calm him down.
Sam, can we please--?
Some things don't deserve to be forgiven.
Man: What do we have?
Forty-five-year-old teacher,
passed out in the middle of a school play.
Now he's complaining about persistent chest pains.
It looks like an acute mi.
What's your plan? He needs to go up for bypass.
I've got a stab wound to the chest to deal with.
Get him to the or. If you need any help--
I'm good. You sure?
Absolutely.
Okay, thanks. Let's go.
Child: When is he coming back?
The kids refused to finish the show. They're really worried.
We're gonna do the best we can, sir.
Okay, so I guess this means no dinner?
Oh, no.
We were to meet Derek and Addison
at the restaurant in 20 minutes.
Oh, well, there's Addison,
so I guess Derek's at the restaurant by himself.
You're doing a bypass on your own.
Yeah. I just got it. Yeah?
Well, I just picked up a bilateral oophorectomy.
I don't start cutting for a couple hours.
Maybe, uh, I can watch?
All right, you guys have fun.
I have a baby-sitter and Derek made the reservations.
I'm having dinner with your husband.
I'll try not to steal him.
Apologize to Derek for me? Naomi: Okay.
Bye-bye.
What's wrong?
Do me a favor. Take this to radiology.
Ask them for a ct angio before the or.
Sure. Thanks.
All right, come on, guys.
Is it worse than you thought? Uh, it might be.
I just-- if there's a chance I'm not gonna make it,
I need to talk to somebody. We can do that for you.
Do you need a priest? I've done some bad things.
And every day I tell myself that I'm gonna stop,
but I can't. Mr. Yates.
I know they're only children, but I can't help myself.
I need to touch them.
I try, but I can't stop.
And I'm so sorry.
Hey. Are you okay?
I will be.
I was with that guy on the elevator.
He seemed nice.
I had no idea.
Maybe this is not a good time. No, please, distract me.
Okay. You should hire me.
Don't beat around the bush on my account.
Well, you've got a nice little practice here.
The baby thing is covered.
You've got shrinks for the screw-ups.
Specialists to handle everything from heart attacks to hernias.
What you don't have is a neurosurgeon.
I'm listening.
I graduated top of my class at Harvard.
I did my residency at Johns Hopkins.
I have published enough research
to single-handedly wipe out several forests.
I'm the real deal, Naomi.
I'm a kick-ass, world-class catch.
Did Addison coach you on how to sell yourself?
No, we haven't discussed it yet.
But you are the big boss now, right?
Look, Amelia, you obviously have impressive credentials.
But this practice is about cooperative medicine,
not solo surgeries.
You could go anywhere you want. Why here?
I like to cut. I won't deny that.
But...
I think that this would be a good environment
for me to broaden my skill set.
Don't give me the rehearsed answer.
I have nowhere else to go
where I'm not alone.
Derek forgave me, but...
I have nowhere else to go.
Oh, hey. I just wanted to let you know
I ordered us the new bed today.
I hope you like it. Don't see why I wouldn't.
Well, you know, it's a lot firmer.
It's basically just a wooden plank.
I don't know if that's your thing, but...
Oh, yeah, and we're getting a dog.
A mastiff, 160 pounds, very drooly.
Gonna sleep in the bed with us.
Dog whisperer, whatever you've gotta say, spit it out.
Because I have to get to the hospital
before hagen's heart Peters out or Sam rips it from his chest.
Why are you house-hunting without me?
Pull up your bra strap, Coop.
I hired a realtor when you kicked me out.
Then we got engaged,
so I told her to look for something bigger.
It's a house, Charlotte.
It's kind of a big deal.
Okay, but we need to move.
What's wrong with the loft?
It's too grungy. Your neighbors are freakishly chipper.
And it'd be nice to sleep with you
in a place that wasn't a fond memory
for half the tramps in L.A.
You know that's not fair.
I went out of my way to make that place feel like ours.
I took down all the vintage Houdini posters.
I let you re-do the bathroom the way you like.
I'm doing cartwheels.
Can we at least agree it's something
that we should consider together?
Fine.
Seeing a house in the palisades tomorrow, 8:00.
Stop whining and you can join me.
This guy, he's got a piece of phosphorous stuck in his thigh.
He's screaming like hell because that stuff burns.
A bullet wound in his back--
Pete's got his hand on my shirt
and he's trying to drag me out of the hut.
Pete: The hut was on fire.
Ugandan rebel army was about to get there--
it was Eritrea. And I wasn't gonna leave the guy.
Uganda. And it was either leave you there or let you get shot.
Can somebody tell me what happened to the guy?
We got him out.
We stabilized him,
then together we carried him four miles
to the nearest refugee camp.
You know, Violet, I like you.
You're beautiful, you're smart.
What the hell are you doing with this guy?
I haven't figured that out yet.
Would you stop flirting? Get your own wife.
This is ridiculous. You've been in town running your clinic
for, what, six months,
and this is the first time we've met?
Gibby is impossible to nail down.
The guy doesn't even have a cell phone.
Never found much use for them in the jungle.
Excuse me.
Come in. Come in. Dr. Gibson, it's my husband.
We were making dinner and he had bad pains in his belly.
It's getting worse.
Rock hard. Could be a perfed appy.
I'll call an ambulance. No, wait.
Give me a hand. On three. One, two, three.
Take him down there.
What are you doing?
Saving his life.
Come on, gibby. We can drive him to the hospital right now.
This is insane.
You could lose your license.
You could be sued for malpractice.
Or I could save his life so his wife doesn't become a widow,
so his kids don't lose their father.
The belly's full of pus. I could really use a hand.
Okay. Pete.
Just until we get him stabilized.
And then I'm out of here. I promise.
Uh, I'm tired.
Sam, you had a right to get angry today.
I know. I mean, he hit Maya.
I don't wanna talk about it.
Sam-- I'm tired.
Good night.
Hey. What do you think,
diplomas behind the desk or on the side wall?
So this is one of the things you were gonna catch me up on?
Pretty cool, huh? Can you hand me that box?
Sure.
Hey, I hope I didn't keep you up last night.
I was nervous about Naomi's decision,
so I just got up and watched a movie.
Uh, no, I was at Sam's.
I didn't even know you were in the house.
So, um, how was Seattle?
I had sex with Mark Sloan. That man has skills.
Face like an angel, hips like the devil, huh? Ha-ha.
Right? Right.
Anyway, it's all turning around for me.
I mean, Derek and I are back on track
and I am starting this fantastic new job.
New job. What?
It's just a little weird
that Naomi didn't mention this to me.
We usually-- we make these decisions as a group.
Oh, she probably figured you wouldn't mind.
I mean, you don't, do you?
No, of course not.
First earthquake,
that house just tumbles right down that hill.
Being on a hill is what gives it those amazing ocean views.
It's gonna have an even better view
when it lands in the actual ocean.
You're just punishing me
because I started looking without you.
You're not listening, Charlotte.
I don't wanna look at all.
Well, I hate your place, Cooper.
Because it reminds me of all the things I screwed up,
all the fights we had.
You not letting me in the front door after you found out
I was building the practice downstairs.
Standing like an idiot with the corn bread chicken casserole
in your bedroom, trying to make up
after I tried to force you to elope.
Fighting over that damn latex jumpsuit
after I bought you into the practice.
And we can't move forward
if that's staring me in the face every day.
You never told me any of this.
Well, now you know.
So...
Amelia works here now.
Yeah, I know. I hired her.
It's a little weird that you decided without telling me.
Well, you decided to sleep with my ex without telling me.
Wow.
Seriously? Well, you know--
babies are tiny terrorists.
I'm dying from sleep deprivation.
Lucas was up five times last night.
Where was Pete? He was operating. In a house.
His friend runs a neighborhood clinic
and he sees no problem
with performing emergency surgeries there.
I-- that cannot be legal.
Probably not the biggest concern his patients have.
He's doing surgeries in a house.
Well, I didn't say I agreed with it, but I get it.
The people he treats probably don't have money or insurance.
They're scared of trying to navigate the system--
even a county hospital is better equipped
to deal with emergencies than someone's living room.
We're talking surgery in an unsterile environment.
The risk of staph infection is huge and--
because nobody ever got a staph infection in a hospital.
Okay. Fine. Well, what about if something goes wrong?
Gibby doesn't have the resources to deal with that.
Things go wrong in hospitals too.
And I'm minding my own business.
I know you're mad that I stayed but--
that guy could have died.
But he didn't and he's home recovering with his family.
So that justifies what you did?
I helped a friend save a guy's life.
Gibby is helping himself. Look, I know.
I know he's trying to do something good here,
but there's-- there's better ways.
There's safer ways of doing that.
Only none of them feed the god complex that he's got going on.
The patient has cad with crescendo angina.
My plan is to cool him down, then do a three-way bypass.
I'll schedule an or for you.
I called in Campbell to handle Mr. Hagen's case.
She's gonna do a cabg.
I don't wanna know. Okay. I respect that.
You want me to leave this up?
What? No.
Are you sure, Sam? Yeah, I gotta go.
Hagen did ask to speak to you.
I told him I'd pass it along.
I told you I don't wanna deal with this.
Addison: What is it?
Sam: Double lumen on a aortic arch.
A dissecting aneurysm? Yeah.
A different surgery altogether.
Are you gonna get your attending up here?
No. I'm gonna scrub in.
Are you sure?
He's a child molester. What?
He thinks that he's gonna die,
so he wanted to get it off his chest.
He's a pedophile. Sam.
I'm doing the surgery.
I can handle it.
Hey. Hold still.
One more minute.
Hey. You're back.
And with gifts.
I noticed you were running low on supplies.
Oh, thanks, man. You're a lifesaver. Last night too.
I hope that didn't rock the boat at home.
It'll blow over.
Listen, I've been thinking about your setup here
and I've got some contacts at surgery centers.
Let me see what kind of deal I can work out for you.
Pete, most of my patients don't even have cars.
None of them wanna be part of a system that's failed them.
I'm fine with what I got. One surgery goes wrong--
I don't remember you being such a worrier.
What's wrong with that little girl?
I don't know. I haven't had time to check her out yet.
This is triage, man. You know the game.
The sicker ones go first.
Hi. Can I look at your arm?
It's popped out of its socket. Here. It's okay.
There. Okay?
Okay.
Okay. Who's next?
Troy hagen's refusing treatment.
But he has unstable angina.
He's gonna die if he doesn't have surgery.
Seems to be the point. Well, it's his choice.
Maybe he's trying to skip jail?
He's not. He feels like he doesn't deserve to live.
Well, has anyone asked Sam to talk to him?
Asked Sam to talk to who about what?
Someone has to convince hagen to have surgery.
Why?
I thought you guys were all into helping people.
Oh, screw him.
I get that you're emotional about this.
I mean, the guy made a mistake.
Does that mean that he deserves to die?
Isn't the question whether we have to go out of our way
to help him live?
Hey. Where have you been? Hey.
I've been calling you for hours.
I was at the clinic with gibby.
I was treating patients.
You missed three appointments.
I know. I'll ask them to reschedule.
I've decided to volunteer at the clinic one afternoon a week.
Pete. There were 20 people
in his waiting room and more standing outside.
People who have nowhere to go, who need help.
You help people here every day. It's not the same.
Our clients have money, they can pay for the care we give.
These people have nothing. They need me.
I get it. And it's noble.
It's just too risky, you know.
For gibby, for the patients, for you.
Okay, spare me the sermon.
I don't wanna give you a sermon. I just--
I want you to think about what you're doing.
I know what I'm doing, Violet.
I thought you'd already be cutting.
Hey. I'm heading in right now.
Well, I'm glad I caught you. Um...
I wore this cap for my first solo surgery, so it's good luck.
Well, I'm already scrubbed in, so could you?
Sure.
You okay? Yeah, yeah. I'm fine.
Sam. Hmm?
You can do this. Yeah, I know I can.
I've done grafts on a hundred pig hearts.
It's not what I meant.
I have a daughter, Addison.
A daughter who's younger than those kids waiting.
It's irrelevant.
Irrelevant? You're his surgeon.
Only thing that should concern you.
Your job isn't to judge his life.
Your job is to save his life. That's all.
Right?
Hey. I--
you need to convince Sam to talk to Troy hagen.
I thought we weren't talking about Sam.
No, I can talk about Sam. You don't get to.
But, uh, you do need to straighten him out.
This is not something that is up for discussion with him.
I know Sam and--
no, no. I know Sam. You're just sleeping with him.
I'm sorry.
I'm sorry.
You really wanna be with Sam?
You need to be with him.
You got to be his sounding board. His conscience.
You need to kick him in the behind when he needs it.
You've got a stubborn man on your hands, Addison,
and it's not okay to just walk away when things get hard.
Step up.
Hey, you're not gonna tell Pete, are you?
What? That we're having lunch on a non-prescribed day?
I'm gonna keep Charlotte in the dark.
I don't even think Pete would care now.
All he's thinking about is how to get back to the jungle
where he can perform open-heart surgery with a pen-knife.
You hate the jungle. You don't like grass.
I think he's struggling with the path not taken.
Wait, I thought he already took that path
and then got off, didn't--?
Well, being around gibby
has obviously tapped into something, you know.
He's so-- he's so happy and re-energized.
And, no, I want him to be happy. I do. I just--
not at any cost.
Pete's no dummy. He's making a choice.
Just like Charlotte who's just deciding she hates my apartment.
We're on to you now? She wants to move.
It's your bachelor pad, Cooper. You can't blame her.
No more than you can blame Pete.
So, what are we gonna do?
Well, you're the shrink.
What would you tell a patient?
I would say you have to confront your problems.
Be honest. And then, you know, whatever happens, happens.
People pay you for that?
Hey.
Wow, that looks like not even a little bit fun.
Yeah. It's just this foundation paperwork.
I-I don't even know where to begin.
Much more interested in just looking
at pictures of Olivia. Aww.
Okay, that baby has my ears too. It must be me.
I have baby ears.
Let me see. No.
Did you need something?
Well, I just wanted to make sure that you were okay.
Oh.
Having Troy hagen show up, yeah, that really threw me.
Yeah.
And I miss William.
But I was talking more about the whole Sam and Addison thing.
And I know from having to watch Violet and Pete,
and Charlotte and Cooper,
that it can make work a little awkward.
I'm fine. You know, Sam and I, we had our shot.
And seems only fair that he and Addison
should have theirs, so I'm fine.
Well, that's an admirable position to take.
I don't wanna be someone who can't move forward.
Sure. Sure.
But sometimes what we wanna be and what we actually feel
can be two different things.
I'm not proud of it, but once when no one was around,
I licked Pete's bagel.
Okay, I'm a little proud of it.
My point is that you should give yourself permission
to use whatever kind of a coping mechanism you need.
Screaming, crying,
maybe even a dart board with both their faces.
Do whatever you need to do.
Trust me, I'm licensed to give that kind of advice.
Violet: What are you doing?
Gibby called. He has an emergency.
Call an ambulance. Let them deal with it.
That's not the way this works.
That's exactly how this works.
When you have an emergency,
call 911 and they take you to the hospital.
I knew you wouldn't understand. Then talk to me.
Explain to me why my husband would risk everything,
his practice, his medical license, his family,
because some old ghost from his past asked him to.
I miss this kind of work, okay?
The rush of it. The way it makes me feel.
I knew you wouldn't understand. Hey, hey, hey.
I used to work with inner-city single moms.
I used to counsel rape victims.
I ran a suicide hotline. I do understand.
But I didn't break any laws doing it.
Don't wait up.
Why are you lurking?
I'm not lurking. I do not lurk.
About the-- this whole Troy hagen thing...
I don't wanna talk about him.
What, Addison?
Why did you quit doing heart surgery before?
Why? I'm not discussing that.
Sam. Just leave it alone.
No.
That patient, that pedophile,
and now Troy hagen.
Just shut up, please?
Shut up.
What did you do, Sam?
Doctors choose to do nothing all the time.
You know it, I know it.
It's the dirty little secret of surgery.
Doctors choose to do nothing.
Wait. When the patient is brain-dead
or is gonna suffer or is too far gone--
doctors choose to do nothing.
They choose to do nothing for the right reasons, Sam.
Tell me. It's okay. Just--
what did you do?
Okay, he's off bypass.
He's in fib. Lost his pulse.
Dr. Bennett?
Sam: Starting cardiac massage. He's still in fib.
Internal paddles ready.
Dr. Bennett?
No pulse with direct massage.
You're losing him. Should I page Dr. Warren?
Sam: No.
Asystole.
Dr. Bennett? Internal paddles ready.
It's over. We should stop.
But-- we should stop.
Sam: Time of death, 20:13.
Woman: Dr. Mendville, 8662. Dr. Mendville--
what the hell happened in there? Keep your voice down.
Sam-- Sam, tell me. I made a judgment call.
I made a call. It was a bad call.
You don't know that. Not for sure.
Nobody knows that. You know that.
Look me in the eye. Tell me that you didn't just--
Addison, I made a call. Leave it alone.
I'm done.
What--? I quit.
I let everybody think that I froze because it was easier,
but I made a choice.
You let him die.
You knew.
You knew I let him die.
I didn't wanna believe it and then you quit surgery,
so I guess I just kind of let it go.
Not everybody deserves our help.
No, not everybody deserves our respect. But our help?
There's nothing you can say right now
that's gonna make me feel any worse than I already do.
Sam.
That surgery was 12 years ago.
You're a different-- you're a different man now.
No, it doesn't matter. Yeah, it does matter.
It matters for you, for us.
And hagen, look, somebody else is gonna do that surgery.
And whatever happens, it's not on you.
No, it's all on me.
I'm just asking you to talk to hagen.
Murderer to murderer?
Pete: What happened?
Girl took three bullets to the abdomen.
We were sitting in the car and, uh, these guys pulled up
and I told her to get down. The bullets were for me.
I get control of one bleeder, two more open up.
She's bleeding faster than I can fix them.
You can save her, right? I mean, you gotta save her.
We've gotta call an ambulance.
No, that wasn't part of the deal.
What? Deal? Deal?
Gibby: Alex and his friends pay me some money from time to time.
You're taking money from gangbangers?
Keeps the office going.
Would you hand me a 3.0 vicryl on a driver?
So you look the other way with criminals
because they're the ones that can pay?
Gibby: For every Alex who can pay,
I can treat a hundred patients who can't.
Don't tell me I'm doing something wrong.
You're risking peoples' lives. Now ours.
We used to do that all the time.
Back then you didn't cry about it.
Well, back then we didn't have a choice. Now we do.
Her pressure's dropping.
She needs blood, platelets, ffp.
Do something. Gibby: I don't have access.
That's why she needs to be in a hospital.
We can cross-clamp her aorta. Try to maintain cns function.
Alex: Put down the phone. Listen to me.
Your girlfriend has about five minutes
before she bleeds out on that table.
And there is nothing, nothing,
that we can do here to change that.
Put down the gun. Let me save her life.
Yeah, I've got a teenaged female.
Multiple gunshot wounds. I need an ambulance.
Hey, I was just coming to find you.
I talked to Sam-- "you're selfish, Addison.
"You always have been.
"The tunnel vision that makes you a great surgeon
also makes you a crappy friend."
What--? Please let me finish.
Sheldon told me to do this.
Just please. I just-- let me finish.
"You're a cheater. And while Sam and I aren't married anymore,
"you knew what you were doing was wrong,
"and so you lied to me.
"Every day, you didn't tell me about the two of you, you lied.
"Because you knew telling the truth would be hard.
"And you're a coward. You're my best friend,
"but when I look at you now,
I just wanna slap you across the face."
Okay, I'm finished.
You sure? I think so.
Feel better? Kind of.
You wanna know why Sam quit surgery 12 years ago?
He let a pedophile die on his table.
What? I--
he made a decision
and it's been eating away at him ever since.
And seeing Troy hagen, it just brought it all back for him.
Nai, I know you're mad at me.
I know that we are--
I can't help him.
He needs you.
I see it on your face when you're here. You feel it.
That thing. The reason we help people.
That girl would have died on your table.
Maybe. Maybe not.
But now everything I've built, they're gonna take it away.
Because you went too far.
You disappoint me.
I've got nothing to prove to you.
And if I hear about another clinic,
if I find out that you treat another patient,
I will personally call the cops and shut you down.
Sam.
Hey.
I talked to Addison. She told me.
She told you what? I know what happened.
Hmm?
I know.
Sam.
Sam. Look at me.
I am. Please, just look at me.
I am.
I understand. No, you can't.
No, Sam, I do.
But you should've told me.
Because after that, everything changed.
Maybe not all at once, but--
but just enough.
Yeah.
Well, I'm sorry. Ahem.
I know.
I don't know if that matters anymore.
